title: BCA's New Generation
text:
He’s got a shaved head, a stubbled face, doesn’t wear a tie and is the first Business Council of Australia president aged under 50, as we reported on page one yesterday. The 49-year-old former MYOB chief executive Tim Reed represents more than generational change. Mr Reed’s background in small business software means he’s not the boss from the big end of town that politicians – both Coalition and Labor – cast as the villain of the piece. He’s not a banker, a miner, a gas exporter or a big energy CEO. His background in using practical technology to help Scott Morrison’s quiet Australians have a go is an opportunity to reset the business community's fractious relationship with the government. What corporate Australia needs now is an articulate and energetic advocate like Mr Reed who can make the public case for big structural reforms in tax, energy, and workplace policy that are urgently needed to boost investment, jobs, productivity and economic growth.

He's not the boss from the big end of town. Louie Douvis
description: The new Business Council of Australia president can reset the relationship between corporate Australia and the Morrison Government.
